S4.T1.3.caption: TABLE I:  Image proportions for different foreground pixel ratios of instances in remote sensing scene and natural scene.
references: NWPU VHR-10. The NWPU VHR-10 dataset[7] we adopt is an extension of the NWPU WHR-10 object detection dataset for instance segmentation, which contains 650 remote sensing optical images. The instance categories of annotations include aircraft, ships, oil tanks, baseball fields, tennis courts, basketball courts, athletic fields, harbours, bridges, and automobiles for a total of 10 categories. As shown in TableÂ I, we performed a statistical analysis based on the annotations provided by the dataset, which shows that 98.9% of the image has less than 20% of instance foreground pixels, which is significantly lower than the COCO dataset of natural scenes. In our experiments, we split the training and validation sets in the ratio of 7:3.

SSDD. The SSDD dataset[28] is a SAR image interpretation dataset containing 1160 SAR images under a variety of conditions, cropped to a resolution of 500*500. The manual annotation used for the instance segmentation task is adopted in experiments, which contained 2456 ships. The statistics in TableÂ I show that 99.5 per cent of the images have a ratio of instance foreground pixels of no more than 10 per cent, and the problem of unbalanced foreground pixels is more prominent. Similarly, we adopt the 7:3 ratio to split the training set and the validation set.

references: In this section, we build ablation experiments to illustrate the effectiveness of the different components of our proposed approach from multiple perspectives, including performance on the overall dataset (TableÂ II), performance on fine-grained categories (FigureÂ 7), and hyper-parameterised ablation (FigureÂ 8).

The local prompt module (LPM) is proposed to better exploit the texture detail information of the instance objects in the local areas from the original image to be used as the prompt information for instance segmentation decoding, which in turn improves the performance of instance segmentation. The second row of TableÂ II shows the results of the baseline model with the addition of this module, which achieves a significant improvement in both detection and segmentation performance compared to the baseline model in the first row. For object detection it improves Aâ¢Pdğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘AP^{d}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 1.3%, Aâ¢P50dğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘50AP^{d}_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 1.5%, Aâ¢P75dğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘75AP^{d}_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 1.6% and for segmentation it improves Aâ¢Psğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP^{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 1.5%, Aâ¢P50sğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ 50AP^{s}_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 1.4%, Aâ¢P75sğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ 75AP^{s}_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 1.6%.
The second column of FigureÂ 7 lists the performance of the fine-grained categories of the model with the LPM embedded. Compared to the baseline model in the first column, our proposed LPM delivers performance improvements on the vast majority of categories, especially for BC and SBF, with instance segmentation and object detection improvements of Aâ¢Ps::ğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ absentAP^{s}:italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT :4.7%, Aâ¢Psğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP^{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 4.3% and Aâ¢Pdğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘AP^{d}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 3.3.%, Aâ¢Pd::ğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘absentAP^{d}:italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT :4.9% respectively.
Achieving such a significant improvement proves that our proposed LPM is indeed able to better exploit the texture detail information of the instances from the original image, and such a prompt are also beneficial for instance segmentation in remote sensing images. In short, our proposed LPM is effective for addressing the problem of remote sensing instance segmentation.

The global prompt module (GPM) is designed to exploit global contextual information to the target instances from the un-downsampled original image, which in turn improves the modelâ€™s performance for instance segmentation in the form of prompt cues. The third row of TableÂ II shows the performance of the model with the GPM embedded. Compared to the baseline model in the first row, our proposed GPM improves Aâ¢Psğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP^{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 2.2%, Aâ¢P50sğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ 50AP^{s}_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 2.6%, Aâ¢P75sğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ 75AP^{s}_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 4.3% in instance segmentation; and Aâ¢Pdğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘AP^{d}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 1.7%, Aâ¢P50dğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘50AP^{d}_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 1.4%, Aâ¢P75dğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘75AP^{d}_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 3.3% in object detection.
The third column of FigureÂ 7 shows the model performance of fine-grained categories with the GPM embedded. Compared to the baseline model in the first column, our proposed GPM achieves an improvement of Aâ¢Psğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP^{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 8.7%, Aâ¢Pdğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘AP^{d}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:8.2% and Aâ¢Psğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP^{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 4.0%, Aâ¢Pdğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘AP^{d}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 5.2% in the SH and HA categories, respectively, and in most of the other categories to varying degrees.
From the analysis, our proposed GPM contains global-to-local prompt paradigm ideas and designed implementation modules that bring different levels of enhancement in overall data and fine-grained categories. In short, our proposed GPM is effective for remote sensing image instance segmentation.

The proposalsâ€™s area loss function (PAreaLoss) is proposed to to add a scale decoupling dimension for the extraction of proposals to achieve more accurate proposals, which in turn exploits the potential of our proposed LPM and GPM to achieve better performance.
Compared to the baseline model in the first row of TableÂ II, the fourth row with the addition of PAreaLoss has an improvement in instance segmentation performance: Aâ¢Psğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP^{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 1.6%, Aâ¢P50sğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ 50AP^{s}_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 0.9%, Aâ¢P75sğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ 75AP^{s}_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 2.3%, and an improvement in object detection performance: Aâ¢Pdğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘AP^{d}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 1.6%, Aâ¢P50dğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘50AP^{d}_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 0.7%, Aâ¢P75dğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘75AP^{d}_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 2.4%. Compared to the baseline (first row), our proposed three components (fifth row) achieve an improvement in instance segmentation: Aâ¢Psğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP^{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 2.7%, Aâ¢P50sğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ 50AP^{s}_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 3.8%, Aâ¢P75sğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ 75AP^{s}_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 4.2% and an improvement in object detection: Aâ¢Pdğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘AP^{d}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 3.2%, Aâ¢P50dğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘50AP^{d}_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 3.2%, Aâ¢P75dğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘75AP^{d}_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 4.7%. In the ablation of the fine-grained categories in FigureÂ 7, PAreaLoss improves to varying degrees in most of the categories, especially for SBF, instance segmentation performance improves by Aâ¢Psğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP^{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 4.1%, and object detection performance improves by Aâ¢Pdğ´superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘AP^{d}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 4.4%. From the analyses, our proposed PAreaLoss indeed improves the performance of instance segmentation due to its benefit of more accurate proposals, which in turn exploits the potential of LPM and GPM. In short, our proposed PAreaLoss is effective for remote sensing image instance segmentation.

The space and time complexity comparisons of our proposed approach are shown in the last two columns of TableÂ II. We use the number of model parameters as model size to illustrate model space complexity, as shown in the last column of TableÂ II. We adopt inference speed Fâ¢Pâ¢Sğ¹ğ‘ƒğ‘†FPSitalic_F italic_P italic_S to illustrate the time complexity of our proposed approach, as shown in the second-last column of TableÂ II.
Although our proposed components bring a little parameter and inference time improvement, it is still able to satisfy the needs of instance segmentation applications, and the improvement of instance segmentation performance is more prominent, therefore, our proposed method is worthwhile.

references:
ISAID:
TableÂ III lists the instance segmentation comparison with other state-of-the-art works on ISAID dataset. We conduct experiments by embedding our proposed prompt paradigm into three models: mask rcnn[3], cascade mask rcnn[16], and scnet[30]. Experimental results based on these three models show that our proposed approach all lead to an improvement in instance segmentation performance, by 2.7% on Mask-RCNN, 2.3% on cascade mask rcnn, and 0.7% on scnet. The best performance scnet embedded with our approach outperforms other state-of-the-art works in Aâ¢Pğ´ğ‘ƒAPitalic_A italic_P, Aâ¢P50ğ´subscriptğ‘ƒ50AP_{50}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Aâ¢P75ğ´subscriptğ‘ƒ75AP_{75}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 75 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Aâ¢Psğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP_{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT metrics. And the cascade mask rcnn embedded with our approach outperforms other state-of-the-art works in Aâ¢Pmğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šAP_{m}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT evaluation metrics. From the above comparative analysis, it can be concluded that our proposed approach is a competitive remote sensing image instance segmentation work on the iSAID dataset.

references: The facilitation between different tasks plays a crucial role in optimising the learning of the model, e.g., the classification task provides instance category information that facilitates the accuracy of instance segmentation, while instance segmentation facilitates object detection in spatial localisation. Therefore, we establish a study on the performance of our proposed approach for the object detection task. After examining the comparison results listed in TableÂ IV, TableÂ VI, TableÂ VIII, and TableÂ X, what can be found is that our proposed approach outperforms the previous works in object detection on all three datasets except the SSDD dataset. From the comparison results in TableÂ VIII, although our approach is not optimal in terms of Aâ¢Pğ´ğ‘ƒAPitalic_A italic_P evaluation metrics, it is superior to other works in terms of Aâ¢Psğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP_{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for small object sets and Aâ¢Plğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™AP_{l}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT metrics for medium object sets. The above analyses show that our proposed approach has a positive impact on object detection task in remote sensing images. The synergistic facilitation between these interrelated tasks helps to improve the model to address complex visual problems in remote sensing images.

NWPU VHR-10:
The results of the comparison with other state-of-the-art works on the NWPU VHR-10 dataset are presented in TableÂ V. According to the comparative results in the table, the cascade mask rcnn[16] embedded with our proposed approach significantly outperforms the other works, both in terms of the evaluation metrics Aâ¢Pğ´ğ‘ƒAPitalic_A italic_P reflected in the performance on the overall data as well as the Aâ¢Psğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP_{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reflected in the performance on the small instance set, the Aâ¢Pmğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šAP_{m}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the medium instance set, and the Aâ¢Plğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™AP_{l}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the large instance set. It can be concluded that our proposed prompt paradigm is a new state-of-the-art instance segmentation work on the NWPU VHR-10 dataset.

references: The facilitation between different tasks plays a crucial role in optimising the learning of the model, e.g., the classification task provides instance category information that facilitates the accuracy of instance segmentation, while instance segmentation facilitates object detection in spatial localisation. Therefore, we establish a study on the performance of our proposed approach for the object detection task. After examining the comparison results listed in TableÂ IV, TableÂ VI, TableÂ VIII, and TableÂ X, what can be found is that our proposed approach outperforms the previous works in object detection on all three datasets except the SSDD dataset. From the comparison results in TableÂ VIII, although our approach is not optimal in terms of Aâ¢Pğ´ğ‘ƒAPitalic_A italic_P evaluation metrics, it is superior to other works in terms of Aâ¢Psğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP_{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for small object sets and Aâ¢Plğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™AP_{l}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT metrics for medium object sets. The above analyses show that our proposed approach has a positive impact on object detection task in remote sensing images. The synergistic facilitation between these interrelated tasks helps to improve the model to address complex visual problems in remote sensing images.

SSDD:
TableÂ VII lists the comparison of our proposed approach with other state-of-the-art works on the SSDD dataset. Compared to other state-of-the-art works, cascade mask rcnn embedded in our proposed prompt paradigm outperforms the performance evaluation metric Aâ¢Pğ´ğ‘ƒAPitalic_A italic_P on the overall dataset and Aâ¢Pmğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šAP_{m}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the medium instance set. For the evaluation metric Aâ¢Psğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP_{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the small instance set, although slightly lower than the last state-of-the-art work RSIISN[10], it is significantly higher than the other works. It can be concluded that our proposed prompt paradigm is a competitive instance segmentation work for remote sensing SAR images on the SSDD dataset.

HRSID:
TableÂ IX lists the comparison of our proposed approach with other state-of-the-art works on the HRSID dataset. From the comparison results, it can be observed that the cascade mask rcnn embedded in our proposed prompt paradigm significantly outperforms other state-of-the-art works. On the overall dataset, the performance improvement over the last state-of-the-art work RSIISN[10], is Aâ¢Pğ´ğ‘ƒAPitalic_A italic_P: 3.5%; on the small instance set, the performance improvement is Aâ¢Psğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ AP_{s}italic_A italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT: 4.0%. While slightly lower than RSIISN on the medium and large target sets, it is still significantly higher than the other work. Taken together, our proposed prompt paradigm is an advanced remote sensing SAR image instance segmentation work on the HRSID dataset.

S4.T11.3.caption: TABLE XI:  Quantitative instance segmentation performance (mask  A â¢ P ğ´ ğ‘ƒ AP italic_A italic_P ) about promptable instance segmentation. â€™ISâ€™ indicates instance segmentation.
references: The quantitative promptable instance segmentation evaluation results are shown in TableÂ XI. For some missed instances of automatic instance segmentation, we input the boxes prompt into the promptable instance segmentation model, output the mask, and finally compute the evaluation metrics together with the automatic instance segmentation results. The reason for the few improvements is that the number of missed instances in the automatic instance segmentation model with our prompt paradigm is less compared to the number of recalled instances, but it is enough to prove that the promptable instance segmentation model constructed on the basis of our proposed prompt paradigm is effective.
